i turned around and it was professor daniel fried from the language technologies institute

then he rappelled off the wall and flew away

Background: Big State School EE Undergrad 3.8 GPA Latin Honors, wanting CS PhD, Skipped GRE, 1 REU + Undergrad research projects, Compelling essay (first gen college student) with passion and diversity focus, undergrad TA experience, EE internship at no name company, decent letters, what percentage would you give me and what schools should I realistically get my hopes up for? I am American with zero connections (yes its possible if your on the poor side).

TTPB: While I agree with the person below about how connections matter and also about the second option of paying your way into a PhD by doing a masters at top 5-10 CS schools, I don't see connections playing a factor in the process being unique to CMU and not every school. Fuck it, not even grad schools, industry is the exact same: connections and your network matter. I would say that most people realize that after a couple years in industry but for those applying to grad schools right out of undergrad, they get to experience earlier than their peers who went to work instead of grad school. And cause of ML/AI hype, the number of applicants is so much that a person who would have been a star candidate 5-10 years ago does not get accepted this cycle or even interviewed. and to the post further below about deferrals, from every school I have interviewed with, the idea that everyone isn't getting cause of people deferring is bullshit. You just have to come terms with the fact that ML hype has made CS exponential crowded and instead of 1-2 extremely overqualified applicants (ie: 4+ NIPS/ICLR/ICML papers), you now have 20-30 of these applicants resulting into the minimum bar to get in increase dramatically. Really the only question left to see is that if this cycle was a 1 time thing or is the bar just going to exponentially increase. Here's to hoping for AI winter #3...

TTPB: Compare to the people who get into these schools? At least this year your profile 'is' average (not the whole pool but the pool that got accepted). There are so many applicants with more than 3+ publications in top conferences, whether that is a good phenomenon I don't know but it is what it is at the current stage. I know one person who got into Stanford has 5 publications in Neurips, ICML, and ICRL... don't even know why that person even needs a Ph.D.

TTPB. I think I would be the best judge for my profile, in MY field and trust me I have enough indicators from other good schools for the same. Although I didn't mention that this is one of the top profile, but I would certain not call it average. Even if it is average, how does that justify a professor willing to take you on but can't because of the strong hold of a committee who is infamous for their weird criteria of rejection. I have also heard that the dropout rate for CMU is very high. This definitely makes me wonder that the randomness factor is extremely high for CMU.

Applied to ML and LTI. Interviewed by profs in LTI mid Jan (thought it went wellâ€”they were definitely nice). Rejected by LTI a few days ago and ML today. 3.97gpa dual degree math and CS in top 20 US university. GRE 169Q, 166V, 5.0A. Research, papers, posters, Google/Microsoft internships, national research scholarships. What can I sayâ€”crazy year for AI/ML admissions. Congrats to those who got in and good luck to the rest to find a good fit somewhere else.

TTPB: Dude, honestly with the current situation of AI/ML your profile is average in the pool (good in other fields). So don't bash CMU, from what I know CMU is one of the few top schools that actually even give students with fewer publications a chance and read your SOP closely while Stanford just weeds out based on your profile. Don't really know about MIT...

(ML Department). 
Background: MS CS from a top university for AI in the US. 1 first author publication in a top ML theory conference. Undergrad from a tier 1 engineering institute in India. Low undergraduate GPA (7.6/10), but that was in 5 years ago. Masters GPA 3.95. I had only heard that CMU metrics were weird, and now I have seen them. I had spoken with a professor who would have admitted me had I passed the first round. If this is their way of selecting candidates, is CMU even a dream school? I am sure MIT, Stanford have a more clear criteria of selecting candidates. CMU isn't so great in TCS anyway! 

P.S. By top I mean ranked within top 15 of US news and top 10 engineering schools in India.

I regret to inform you that you have not been admitted to the Ph.D. in Robotics program at Carnegie Mellon University. You will be notified by separate email from each program to which you have applied. Our admissions committee scrutinizes applications to identify and compose a group with best potential for cutting-edge robotics research in our institute. We can support only a limited number of new students, about 40, yet we received over 885 applications this year.  Many applicants have strong qualifications and will likely go on to successful careers in robotics.  I wish you the best in your future endeavors.

David S. Wettergreen 
Associate Director for Education 
Chair, Robotics Doctoral Program
By the way, 40 admitted students over 885 applicants.

To those students thinking about coming to CMU and getting into the Ph.D. program after the master's program. 
This is not a cakewalk ride - it actually depends on the person whom you are working with. CMU is a cash cow and if there is no cash you can get literally screwed. There are several factors which come into play and in fact even for the jobs these days all that matters is the kind of work you have done and not where you are from. Remember this and make your decision. 
PS - I have done my masters at CMU and do know all kinds of details

To the posters asking about CMU rejection mail. Yes, CMU sends out a rejection email. If you are not getting the rejection then it can be because your application was not submitted on time. It can be either due to late online payment/submission or if one or more of your recommenders had not submitted their letter(s) on time, i.e. the deadline (10th Dec 2018). Hope this helps.

For all those people who got in to CMU PhD, which department did you get in? Did anyone here from CSD or RI? Thanks in advance.

Basically, each department at CMU has its own admission process and schedule. So, It looks like CSD sent out their decision. Not yet the other department. Another note is that CMU has no multiple rounds. Single decision for all.  If you didn't hear any news but someone did, you are very likely to be turned down.
My area of specialization was Large Scale Networks and Network Security.
